title: It's a wonder anyone still lives in Bilgewater, no matter how prosperous the trade
body:
You're likely to be:

* killed by sea monsters
* killed by the harrowing
* killed by pirates at sea
* killed by rival gang members
* killed in a crossfire
* killed in a mugging
* killed by disease
* killed because you saw something you weren't meant to see
* killed because you didn't pay on time
* killed because you looked at them funny
* killed because you fell off a dock and drowned
* killed because they were angry
* killed because they were drunk
* killed because they could
* killed by Pyke, whose murder list conveniently contains everyone he meets
* killed by Nautilus
* killed because of Fizz's antics
* eaten by Tahm Kench

and these are just the ones I can name off the top of my head. Sure, there was a pirate city like Port Royal in real life, but with added things such as ghost serial killers, regular undead invasions, and an overabundance of vicious sea monsters, it seems even worse.

Edit: It's not that people wouldn't try. Humans are tenacious, and the prospect of wealth is alluring. I'm just surprised that there's anybody left _alive_ in Bilgewater because all of these things happen in the same town.

The thing to remember is that while all this bad stuff can happen, it's not the only stuff that happens. People die a lot, but given that a lot of people wander about without getting killed shows that it's not a permanent PUBG game. It's a lawless city, but it seems like there are tules to the place, like the bilgewater tithe existed before Nautilus was a giant, so it's not impossible there are unspoken rules that keep normal people from just being mass murderers. Basically, it's certainly something of a hell hole, but it's got more to it. If you list only the bad of any place, any place will sound inhospitable.

Looking more into some of your specific points, you only get killed by Nautilus if he doesn't collect your payment, and while Fizz certainly steals Tithes from time to time, the large number of ships that don't get killed by Nautilus shows that Fizz isn't constantly screwing people over. Tahm Kench only targets people who are desperate, and even then isn't a force specific to Bilgewater. His bio talks about him showing up in Piltover, so he's not the best example for why Bilgewater shouldn't be lived in. Pyke certainly kills a lot of people, but that doesn't seem to be everything he does. I mean, it's his occupation but he's been doing this for years and hasn't made much of a dent in the Bilgewater population.

A good chunk of your other points could fit with almost any city with gang violence, or any violence at all really. Bilgewater just lacks a legal system, and even then as previously stated it's not just a free for all. And there's good too. You can make your fortune, sail the seas, discover ancient treasure, and more. People will always have their reasons for living in certain places. Why does anyone live in Zaun? Because there they can make what they want, and sometimes save lives or do amazing things that they wouldn't be able to do in Piltover. It's like that.
I also imagine Bilgewater as a low class area where thugs, exiles, criminals, refugees, etc. go to for a home since they have nowhere else to go.
So it essentially sounds like Chaos vs. Order.

I wouldn't even say that, because there aren't law people going around trying to keep the violence under control. Miss Fortune is a bounty hunter but she needs personal gain to actually do a job, she doesn't just kill for the sake of keeping the peace. It's a lawless place, and there's no straight up good force in it, it's just a place where people live their way but don't always do whatever they want because they have to live there too. There can never really be order, since the entire city is founded on lawlessness and true freedom, but it's not just a constant fight for your life.

Also remember, I don't think Pyke will murder you if you're not a sailor of any kind. The general population of tanners, blacksmiths, fishmongers, prostitutes, tavern owners and everyone else who conducts business in the city, and not out at sea, would be safe, since they wouldn't have been part of a crew and thus end up on Pyke's list. As far as we've seen, he's killing captains, first mates, and people who've served on pretty much ANY ship, but we don't have any records of Pyke killing people who haven't served on a ship.

Not a single one of your arguments hold under close scrutiny. I certainly wouldn't want to live in Demacia myself, they are far too conservative for my taste, but you're far less likely to have to fight in war as a Demacian citizen compared to someone from Noxus. The latest story with the emissaries from the Iron-what's-its-name mountain clearly marks them as a unique exception because they never had to provide soldiers to the empire. Meaning EVERY other region is regularly having conscription.

Blame Demacia for what they actually deserve to be blamed: they are a bunch of hypocrites, who cling to tradition for its own sake and forgot what's the true goal of a good society, and why those traditions were established in the first place. They strangle their people in customs and hierarchical structures. But they don't send them to war recklessly.

RE: numbers, don't forget that such a juicy target is likely to have to guard all of it at all times: total numbers mean a lot less if they're spread around too much. The Demacians can easily be both more numerous than anyone else and also outnumbered in every fight if their current opponents are Noxus, Zaun, and Bilgewater Raiders at the same time on multiple fronts.

The plot twist is that nobody lives in Bilgewater, they're all already dead and roam the ghost town.

Yeah it seems like there wouldn't be anybody living in Bilgewater who's just a regular citizen. Sort of a den of thieves kind of thing, everyone there is capable and deadly, in one way or another, so they can look out for themselves. Anybody who doesn't fit that description probably dies within their first month in town, if not the first week.

You can see evidence of it in Miss Fortunes latest short story, when she's on the dock and the man is walking out to meet her, a gang of weaker people follow him waiting to see if he collapses and would thus be no threat to them if they tried to rob him. An unconscious person cannot shoot or stab you for taking their gold.

I'd be really interested to find out how things are actually run in Bilgewater. It doesn't feel like we understand how the whole city runs, or even if there is anything keeping it running or if they're all just lucky as hell that it hasn't fallen apart under their feet.

What I think would be most likely is that it was built by somebody else, and pirates simply invaded and took over. Pirates (at least in the way we know of them) were not individuals keen on doing the sort of work it would take to build a city. So either the city is ramshackle and hobbled together, or it was previously built and is becoming run-down over time as the pirates make no effort to perform upkeep on the city.
